author: shdwbld
body:
This. There wouldn't be Apple without Steve Jobs and there wouldn't be Tesla, nor SpaceX, likely not even PayPal without Elon Musk. Those scientists and engineers didn't magically materialize around them from thin air. Brilliant minds have always been here, but for large projects such as these you need an individual with a vision, self-drive to act upon it and make enough money for a company to survive in the process at least. And people like these are few and far between for some reason. They are deservedly in the spotlight, because they are leaders that made those projects a reality. Yes, those scientists and engineers did the vast majority of the "manual labor", but they wouldn't do it on their own, if somebody didn't brought them together, gave them a common direction and paid them for their work. 

I'm an engineer, but I don't understand this devaluing of leadership and management in the company that some people do, as if it is somehow less important. I'm talking about real management and leadership of course, not a human centipede of kinder-management sticking from the asses of their superiors in the corporate ladder of halfway disintegrated corporations (looking at you, IBM).

author: vacalicious
body:
In terms of books I'm a big fan of:

 The Little Book That Still Beats the Market — Joel Greenblatt

Rule #1 — Phil Town

Both do a great job of describing market fundamentals, and then present two very different investing strategies. Greenblatt says to buy blue chippers and worry later, while Town argues that you should only buy the dip. Both are valid strategies that have made me money, and show how there are multiple ways to succeed in stocks.

In terms of YouTubers, I follow too many to list. Jeremy from [Financial Education](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCnMn36GT_H0X-w5_ckLtlgQ) is the obvious place to start, and then start branching out from there as you find more YouTubers who match your investing style and/or stock portfolio. As someone who owns Chinese stocks, I like the pleasantly British, animal-loving, Hong Kong-based [Felix Finance](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCJtfma0mE_XrBAD9uakcjfA).

I might get hate for this, but I watch a lot of CNBC, including Squawk on the Street, Fast Money, and Mad Money. All of those shows keep me perfectly in tune with the market, and have made me money. Just from this past year, CNBC helped me get a jump on PayPal, CRM, Tapestry and CVX.

As for podcasts, the best is probably [Best Stocks Now](https://www.gundersoncapital.com/radio-show-archives/). Since reddit trends younger and liberal, I always warn that this podcast host is a Republican Baby Boomer — but boy does he know his stocks. All the Motley Fool and Seeking Alpha podcasts are also worth checking out.

SolarCity was going bust and had to be bailed out. He was literally kicked out of PayPal, I don't know why retards here give him credit for that. He was there for 9 months and did jack shit. 

With the way he treated Eberhard, he seems like a real fucking sociopath and asshole. I can't imagine selling the 2nd roadster made to your friend, when it was promised that Eberhard would get it. And then the car Eberhard got was fucking wrecked by the employee when test driving it on the 101.

Elon understand the madness of the crowd and embraces it. That's why he's so successful and that's why he's admired here. And he's gotten so rich to the point he has connections to high places in government.

author: vacalicious
body: Typical tech correction where everyone took profits in the high-flyers to buy up another round of reopening stocks. We've seen this happen several times now since last March. As someone who owns a lot of tech, it was a bloodbath in my portfolio. But you should buy when there's blood on the streets, even your own. I added to my Nio, PayPal and QCOM positions today, and grabbed some WMT as well, which sold off for shortsighted reasons.

author: bridgeheadone
body:
People who rag on growth tech fail to understand the scalability. 

It is not a production line and they don’t need significant capex to grow. It is digital roll out and marketing. Scalability. Profit growth. 

That’s why companies like Adobe, Microsoft, PayPal, Amazon etc can sustain 20% growth yoy with super high margins. They don’t need to hire 4000 workers or buy 600 hydraulic presses to grow to the same extent as an auto manufacturer. Obviously they need to invest, but they can scale soooo much faster and cheaper.

author: interfail
body:
I'm going to quote exactly what you said:

>And he actually earned it with viable products and services.

Viable products and services are things people can use. Even do use. Guess what Amazon is good at.

Musk's got his contribution to Paypal, and to Tesla which started looking like it's actually doing stuff rather than promising stuff in the last couple of years.

SpaceX is still a pretty minor practical change from previous satellite launches. Starlink barely operates. Neuralink and Hyperloop don't at all.

Yes, they have potential, but they're not "viable products and services" in the same way as something you've been using every day of the last decade of your life, *even though you apparently tried not to*.

author: KnightB7
body: Price seems high right now with a lot of irrational exuberance. Fact of the matter is the market cap has to increase by over half a trillion dollars just to double. IMO way better plays in disruptive tech out there that actually have a viable product and earnings. I also dont like the fact that you cant safely invest a large amount of money in the coins and hold them without a high risk . Many people have lost hundreds of millions in Bitcoin when they lost access to their private keys through whatever means. It also kind of annoys me that I cant buy a lot of these coins in my brokerage acct. and almost 12 years later there is still not an ETF with a good mix of crypto you can just buy without a premium. I say skip it, who cares if it goes to a million, too much uncertainty and you can find stuff out there that is a lot more likely to keep doubling with lower risk (ex. cannabis oplays, SPCE, JMIA etc.). Theoretically I own some BTC through all my ARK ETFs which have a lot of companies that either own or process crypto transactions, such as SQ and PYPL, ICE etc, that is the safer way to play it. Also safer may be BLOK ETF for indirectly owning crypto without huge risk when it tanks.
